title: Earning Differences
description: Explore how earning differences affect your relationship dynamic.

questions.text: When it comes to who earns more in a relationship, I believe...
choices: It doesn't matter—we're a team
It can create power dynamics to watch
Whoever earns more may feel more pressure
It naturally affects how we split things

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about earning differences reveal values about equality, power, and partnership. Team-viewers minimize difference; power-watchers see dynamics; pressure-seers empathize with earners; splitters see practical implications. These beliefs shape how you navigate differences.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs may surface if earning gaps grow. The team-viewer may not see the power-watcher's concerns; the splitter may seem transactional to the team-viewer. Name your beliefs before they become issues.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared beliefs about earning differences mean you'll navigate them similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about earning differences in relationships? Has that affected a relationship before?

questions.text: If one of us earns significantly more, I'd want that person to...
choices: Contribute more to shared expenses
Treat us both to nice things
Not feel responsible for carrying more
Decide together how to handle it

therapeutic.rationale: Expectations of higher earners reveal fairness values. Proportional-contributors see fairness in ratios; treaters see generosity; burden-relievers see emotional cost; discussers want partnership. Unspoken expectations cause resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different expectations may clash if income gaps exist or grow. The proportional-contributor may feel the burden-reliever doesn't contribute enough; the burden-reliever may feel pressured. Talk about it explicitly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared expectations make navigating income differences easier. You agree on what's fair.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: If you earned significantly more than your partner, how would you want to handle it? What if they earned more?

questions.text: If one of us took time off work (for any reason), I'd feel...
choices: Supportive—we make decisions together
Concerned about the financial impact
Depends on the reason and our situation
Like we'd need to plan carefully first

therapeutic.rationale: Reactions to work breaks reveal values about partnership, security, and roles. Supportive types prioritize partnership; concerned types prioritize security; contextual types evaluate; planners need preparation. These reactions surface during career transitions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The supportive partner may feel the concerned partner is unsupportive; the concerned partner may feel the supportive partner is unrealistic. Both care—just about different things.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reactions mean you'll navigate career changes similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you feel if your partner wanted to take time off work? What would you need to feel okay about it?

questions.text: My feelings about my own earning power are...
choices: Confident—I feel good about my contribution
Working on it—I want to earn more
Complicated—it affects how I feel about myself
Not central to my identity

therapeutic.rationale: Earning identity affects self-worth and relationship dynamics. Confident types are secure; working-on-it types have goals; complicated types have identity tied to income; non-central types find worth elsewhere. Partners' earning identities interact.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different earning identities may create misunderstanding. The confident partner may not see the complicated partner's struggle; the non-central partner may not understand why it matters so much.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared earning identity means you understand each other's relationship with work and income.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your earning power affect how you feel about yourself? Is that healthy?

questions.text: The conversation I'd want us to have about earning is...
choices: How to support each other's career growth
How earnings affect our dynamic, honestly
How to make sure neither feels lesser
Our goals and how earnings help us get there

therapeutic.rationale: Desired conversations reveal priorities. Career-supporters want mutual growth; dynamic-explorers want honesty; equality-guarders want emotional safety; goal-focusers want alignment. All conversations are valuable.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conversation priorities reveal different concerns. Make room for all of them—they're all important.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conversation priority focuses your earning discussions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would you most want your partner to understand about your relationship with earning?
